canonical_explanation.text: Motion is the change in position of an object with respect to time. Objects can undergo different types of motion such as rectilinear (straight line), circular, periodic (repeating at regular intervals), and oscillatory (back and forth about a mean position). Speed measures how fast an object moves and is calculated as the distance covered divided by the time taken. The SI unit of speed is metre per second (m/s). Uniform motion means the object covers equal distances in equal intervals of time, while non-uniform motion means unequal distances in equal intervals. Time is measured using clocks and watches; the SI unit of time is the second. A simple pendulum can be used to measure time because it takes the same time for each oscillation (its time period). Distance-time graphs help us visualize and compare the motion of objects.
rules: Motion is the change in position of an object with time.
Rectilinear motion: movement in a straight line.
Circular motion: movement along a circular path.
Periodic motion: motion that repeats at regular intervals.
Oscillatory motion: to and fro movement about a mean position.
SI unit of speed is m/s; km/h is also commonly used.
Uniform motion: equal distances in equal time intervals.
Non-uniform motion: unequal distances in equal time intervals.
SI unit of time is the second (s).
A simple pendulum completes one oscillation in a fixed time called its time period.
Distance-time graph for uniform motion is a straight line; for non-uniform motion it is curved.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of rectilinear motion?

options.text: A ball rolling in a straight line on the ground
A pendulum swinging back and forth
The Earth revolving around the Sun

questions.explanation_correct: A ball rolling in a straight line is an example of rectilinear motion because the object moves along a straight path. This is the defining feature of rectilinear motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A merry-go-round spinning is circular motion, a pendulum swinging is oscillatory motion, and the Earth revolving around the Sun is circular (orbital) motion. Only a ball rolling in a straight line represents rectilinear motion.

questions.question_text: The motion of a child on a swing is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: A child on a swing moves back and forth about a mean (central) position repeatedly. This to-and-fro motion about a fixed point is called oscillatory motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The swing does not move in a straight line (rectilinear), it does not complete a full circle (circular), and its path is predictable and repetitive, not random. The correct classification is oscillatory motion.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of periodic motion?

options.text: A car moving on a highway
A stone thrown in the air

questions.explanation_correct: The hands of a clock repeat their motion at regular intervals (every 12 hours for the hour hand, every 60 minutes for the minute hand, every 60 seconds for the second hand). Motion that repeats itself at regular intervals is called periodic motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A car on a highway does not repeat the same motion at regular intervals, a bee flying is random motion, and a stone thrown in the air undergoes projectile motion which does not repeat. Only the clock hands exhibit periodic motion.

questions.question_text: The motion of the Earth around the Sun is an example of circular motion.
questions.explanation_correct: The Earth moves around the Sun in a nearly circular path (orbit). Since it follows a curved, closed path around the Sun, this is an example of circular motion. It is also periodic because it repeats every year.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The Earth does revolve around the Sun in a nearly circular orbit, making it an example of circular motion.

questions.question_text: A spinning top only exhibits circular motion and no other type of motion.
questions.explanation_correct: A spinning top exhibits rotational motion (spinning around its own axis). It may also show oscillatory motion as it wobbles. Calling it only circular motion is incorrect because circular motion refers to movement along a circular path, which is different from rotation about an axis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. A spinning top has rotational motion (spinning on its axis), not just circular motion. Circular motion involves an object moving along a circular path, which is different from rotation about an axis.

questions.question_text: The formula for calculating speed is:
questions.explanation_correct: Speed is defined as the distance travelled divided by the time taken. The formula is Speed = Distance / Time. This tells us how fast an object is moving.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Speed is not found by multiplying distance and time, dividing time by distance, or adding them together. The correct formula is Speed = Distance / Time.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of speed is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI (International System) unit of speed is metre per second, written as m/s. This comes from the SI unit of distance (metre) divided by the SI unit of time (second).
questions.explanation_incorrect: While km/h is commonly used for vehicle speeds, it is not the SI unit. cm/min and m/min are also not SI units. The SI unit of speed is m/s.

questions.question_text: If a car travels 100 km in 2 hours, its speed is ___ km/h.
questions.explanation_correct: Speed = Distance / Time = 100 km / 2 h = 50 km/h. The car covers 50 kilometres in every hour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: To find speed, divide the distance by the time: 100 km / 2 h = 50 km/h. Do not multiply or add the values.

questions.question_text: An object that covers equal distances in equal intervals of time is said to be in:
questions.explanation_correct: When an object covers equal distances in equal intervals of time, its speed remains the same throughout. This is called uniform motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Non-uniform motion involves covering unequal distances in equal time intervals. Oscillatory motion is back-and-forth motion. Random motion has no fixed pattern. Covering equal distances in equal time is specifically called uniform motion.

questions.question_text: When an object covers unequal distances in equal intervals of time, it is said to be in ___ motion.
questions.explanation_correct: When an object covers unequal (different) distances in equal intervals of time, its speed keeps changing. This type of motion is called non-uniform motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is non-uniform. If an object covers unequal distances in equal intervals of time, its speed is not constant, so the motion is non-uniform.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of time is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI (International System) unit of time is the second, denoted by 's'. While minutes, hours, and days are commonly used, they are not the base SI unit of time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Although minutes, hours, and days are used in everyday life, the base SI unit of time is the second (s). All other time units are derived from the second.

questions.question_text: One complete to-and-fro movement of a pendulum is called:
questions.explanation_correct: One complete to-and-fro movement of a pendulum (from one extreme position to the other and back) is called one oscillation. The time taken to complete one oscillation is called the time period.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Time period is the time for one oscillation, not the oscillation itself. Frequency is the number of oscillations per second. Amplitude is the maximum displacement from the mean position. One complete back-and-forth motion is called an oscillation.

questions.question_text: The time period of a simple pendulum depends on the weight of the bob.
questions.explanation_correct: The time period of a simple pendulum does not depend on the weight (mass) of the bob. It depends primarily on the length of the pendulum. A heavier or lighter bob with the same length will have the same time period.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. The time period of a simple pendulum depends on the length of the pendulum, not on the mass of the bob.

questions.question_text: The time taken by a pendulum to complete one oscillation is called its ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The time taken by a pendulum to complete one full oscillation (one complete to-and-fro movement) is called its time period. It is usually denoted by the letter T.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'time period'. The time period is the specific term for the time taken for one complete oscillation of a pendulum.

questions.question_text: In a distance-time graph, what does a straight line inclined to the time axis indicate?

options.text: The object is in uniform motion
The object is in non-uniform motion

questions.explanation_correct: A straight line inclined to the time axis in a distance-time graph means the object covers equal distances in equal intervals of time, indicating uniform motion with constant speed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A horizontal line (parallel to time axis) indicates the object is at rest. A curved line indicates non-uniform motion. A straight line inclined to the time axis represents uniform motion.

questions.question_text: In a distance-time graph, a horizontal line parallel to the time axis means the object is:
questions.explanation_correct: A horizontal line parallel to the time axis in a distance-time graph means the distance is not changing with time. If the distance remains constant, the object is not moving, so it is at rest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A horizontal line means the distance stays the same as time passes, which can only happen if the object is at rest. Moving objects would show an increasing distance over time.

questions.question_text: A curved line on a distance-time graph indicates that the object is in non-uniform motion.
questions.explanation_correct: A curved line on a distance-time graph means the object covers different distances in equal time intervals, indicating its speed is changing. This is non-uniform motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. A curved distance-time graph shows that the object's speed is not constant, meaning it covers different distances in equal time intervals, which is the definition of non-uniform motion.

questions.question_text: The back and forth motion of a pendulum about its mean position is called ___ motion.
questions.explanation_correct: The to-and-fro or back-and-forth motion of a pendulum about its mean (central) position is called oscillatory motion. It is a type of periodic motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'oscillatory'. A pendulum swings back and forth about its mean position, which is the defining characteristic of oscillatory motion.

questions.question_text: Which instrument in a vehicle shows the distance travelled?
questions.explanation_correct: An odometer is the instrument in a vehicle that measures and displays the total distance travelled. The speedometer shows speed, not distance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A speedometer shows speed, not distance. A thermometer measures temperature and a barometer measures atmospheric pressure. The odometer is the instrument that measures total distance travelled.

questions.question_text: The instrument used to measure the speed of a vehicle is called a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A speedometer is the instrument on a vehicle's dashboard that shows how fast the vehicle is moving at any instant. It displays the speed in km/h or m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'speedometer'. This is the specific instrument designed to measure and display the instantaneous speed of a vehicle.

questions.question_text: A train travels 180 km in 3 hours. What is its average speed?
questions.explanation_correct: Average speed = Total distance / Total time = 180 km / 3 h = 60 km/h. The train covers 60 km every hour on average.
questions.explanation_incorrect: To find average speed, divide total distance by total time. 180 / 3 = 60 km/h. Multiplying (540) or adding/subtracting gives incorrect results.

questions.question_text: A cyclist covers 500 metres in 50 seconds. What is the cyclist's speed in m/s?
questions.explanation_correct: Speed = Distance / Time = 500 m / 50 s = 10 m/s. The cyclist moves 10 metres every second.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using Speed = Distance / Time: 500 / 50 = 10 m/s. The other options result from incorrect calculations.

questions.question_text: A bus travels at a speed of 40 km/h for 2 hours and then at 60 km/h for 1 hour. What is the total distance covered?
questions.explanation_correct: Distance in first part = Speed x Time = 40 x 2 = 80 km. Distance in second part = 60 x 1 = 60 km. Total distance = 80 + 60 = 140 km.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The total distance is found by adding the distance for each part of the journey. First part: 40 km/h x 2 h = 80 km. Second part: 60 km/h x 1 h = 60 km. Total = 140 km.

questions.question_text: A boy runs 200 m in 40 seconds. His speed is ___ m/s.
questions.explanation_correct: Speed = Distance / Time = 200 m / 40 s = 5 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: To calculate speed, divide distance by time: 200 / 40 = 5 m/s.

questions.question_text: Which of the following motions is both periodic and oscillatory?

options.text: A car moving on a straight road
The pendulum of a wall clock
A stone dropped from a height

questions.explanation_correct: The pendulum of a wall clock swings back and forth (oscillatory) and repeats its motion at regular intervals (periodic). It is an example of motion that is both periodic and oscillatory.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A car on a straight road is rectilinear, a spinning wheel is circular/rotational (periodic but not oscillatory), and a stone dropped from a height does not repeat its motion. Only the pendulum is both periodic and oscillatory.

questions.question_text: A pendulum completes 20 oscillations in 40 seconds. What is its time period?
questions.explanation_correct: Time period = Total time / Number of oscillations = 40 s / 20 = 2 seconds. The pendulum takes 2 seconds to complete one oscillation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Time period is calculated by dividing total time by the number of oscillations. 40 / 20 = 2 seconds. Dividing the wrong way (20/40 = 0.5) or using the raw numbers gives incorrect answers.

questions.question_text: If you increase the length of a simple pendulum, what happens to its time period?
questions.explanation_correct: When the length of a simple pendulum is increased, the pendulum takes more time to complete one oscillation, so the time period increases. A longer pendulum swings more slowly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Increasing the length of a pendulum increases its time period because the bob has a longer arc to travel. It does not decrease, stay the same, or fluctuate.

questions.question_text: A pendulum completes 15 oscillations in 30 seconds. Its time period is ___ seconds.
questions.explanation_correct: Time period = Total time / Number of oscillations = 30 / 15 = 2 seconds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Time period = Total time / Number of oscillations = 30 / 15 = 2 seconds. Do not multiply or subtract the values.

questions.question_text: From a distance-time graph, how can you determine which of two objects is moving faster?

options.text: The one with a steeper (more inclined) line is faster
The one with a flatter line is faster
The one with a horizontal line is faster
Both move at the same speed regardless of the line

questions.explanation_correct: In a distance-time graph, a steeper line means the object covers more distance in the same time, indicating a higher speed. The slope of the line represents the speed of the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A flatter line means less distance is covered per unit time (slower). A horizontal line means the object is at rest. The steepness (slope) of the line directly represents the speed.

questions.question_text: An object travels 10 m in the first 2 seconds, 20 m in the next 2 seconds, and 30 m in the following 2 seconds. What type of motion is this?
questions.explanation_correct: The object covers different distances (10 m, 20 m, 30 m) in equal time intervals (2 seconds each). Since the distances are unequal, this is non-uniform motion. Its speed is increasing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For uniform motion, the object must cover equal distances in equal time intervals. Here the distances are 10 m, 20 m, and 30 m (all different) in equal 2-second intervals, so it is non-uniform motion.

questions.question_text: If two objects travel the same distance but one takes less time, the one that takes less time has a higher speed.
questions.explanation_correct: Since Speed = Distance / Time, for the same distance, a shorter time gives a higher speed. The object that takes less time is indeed faster.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Speed = Distance / Time. For the same distance, dividing by a smaller time gives a larger speed.

questions.question_text: In a distance-time graph, the slope of the line represents the speed of the object.
questions.explanation_correct: The slope (steepness) of a distance-time graph equals distance divided by time, which is the speed. A steeper slope means greater speed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The slope of a distance-time graph is calculated as change in distance divided by change in time, which gives the speed.

questions.question_text: A girl is sitting in a moving bus. With respect to a person standing on the road, the girl is in:
questions.explanation_correct: With respect to the person standing on the road, the girl's position is continuously changing as the bus moves. So, relative to the person on the road, the girl is in motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The girl in the moving bus is changing her position relative to the person on the road. She is in motion with respect to the person on the road, even though she may be at rest with respect to the bus.

questions.question_text: To convert speed from km/h to m/s, you should:
questions.explanation_correct: To convert km/h to m/s, divide by 3.6. This is because 1 km = 1000 m and 1 h = 3600 s, so 1 km/h = 1000/3600 m/s = 1/3.6 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Multiplying by 3.6 converts m/s to km/h, not the other way. Dividing by 3.6 correctly converts km/h to m/s.

questions.question_text: A car moves at 72 km/h. In m/s, this speed is ___ m/s.
questions.explanation_correct: To convert km/h to m/s, divide by 3.6. So 72 / 3.6 = 20 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: To convert km/h to m/s, divide by 3.6: 72 / 3.6 = 20 m/s.

questions.question_text: Why was the simple pendulum historically used to measure time?

options.text: Because its time period changes with each swing
Because it always swings in a perfect circle
Because it takes the same time for each oscillation

questions.explanation_correct: A simple pendulum of fixed length takes the same amount of time for each complete oscillation (constant time period). This regularity made it useful as a time-measuring device in early clocks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pendulum was useful because of its constant time period (not changing), not because of a circular path or perpetual motion. The key property is that each oscillation takes the same time.

questions.question_text: On a distance-time graph, non-uniform motion is represented by a ___ line.
questions.explanation_correct: Non-uniform motion means the speed is changing. On a distance-time graph, this produces a curved line because the distance covered per unit time keeps changing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'curved'. A straight line represents uniform motion (constant speed), while a curved line represents non-uniform motion (changing speed).

questions.question_text: An ant covers a distance of 2 m in 100 seconds. A snail covers 1 m in 200 seconds. Which one is faster?
questions.explanation_correct: Speed of ant = 2/100 = 0.02 m/s. Speed of snail = 1/200 = 0.005 m/s. Since 0.02 > 0.005, the ant is faster.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Compare their speeds: ant = 2 m / 100 s = 0.02 m/s; snail = 1 m / 200 s = 0.005 m/s. The ant has a higher speed, so it is faster.

questions.question_text: Classify the following as rectilinear, circular, oscillatory, or periodic motion: (i) Motion of a sewing machine needle, (ii) Motion of a satellite around the Earth, (iii) Motion of a ball rolling on a flat surface.
questions.explanation_correct: The needle of a sewing machine moves up and down repeatedly, making it oscillatory. A satellite orbits Earth in a circular path repeatedly, so it is circular and periodic. A ball rolling on a flat surface moves in a straight line, which is rectilinear motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A sewing machine needle goes up and down (oscillatory), a satellite follows a circular orbit repeatedly (circular and periodic), and a ball rolling straight is rectilinear. Option A correctly classifies all three.

questions.question_text: Rahul cycles to school 3 km away in 15 minutes and returns home in 20 minutes. What is his average speed for the entire trip?
questions.explanation_correct: Total distance = 3 + 3 = 6 km. Total time = 15 + 20 = 35 minutes = 35/60 hours. Average speed = 6 / (35/60) = 6 x 60/35 = 360/35 = 10.3 km/h (approximately).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Average speed = Total distance / Total time. Total distance = 6 km. Total time = 35 minutes = 35/60 h. Average speed = 6 / (35/60) = 10.3 km/h approximately. Using only one-way distance or time gives wrong answers.

questions.question_text: Look at these distance-time data for an object: at t=0s distance=0m, t=2s distance=10m, t=4s distance=20m, t=6s distance=30m. What can you conclude?

options.text: The object is in non-uniform motion
The object is in uniform motion with speed 5 m/s
The object is in uniform motion with speed 10 m/s

questions.explanation_correct: The object covers equal distances (10 m) in equal time intervals (2 s each). This is uniform motion. Speed = 10 m / 2 s = 5 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal distances (10 m each) in equal time intervals (2 s each) means uniform motion. Speed = distance per interval / time per interval = 10/2 = 5 m/s, not 10 m/s.

questions.question_text: A simple pendulum takes 32 seconds to complete 16 oscillations. If the length of the pendulum is doubled, what can you predict about its new time period?

options.text: It increases to more than 2 seconds
It decreases to less than 2 seconds

questions.explanation_correct: Original time period = 32/16 = 2 seconds. Increasing the length of a pendulum increases its time period. So the new time period will be more than 2 seconds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The original time period is 32/16 = 2 seconds. Since increasing length increases the time period, the answer must be more than 2 seconds. It does not stay the same or decrease.

questions.question_text: A car travels 120 km at 60 km/h and then another 120 km at 40 km/h. What is the average speed of the car for the whole journey?
questions.explanation_correct: Time for first part = 120/60 = 2 hours. Time for second part = 120/40 = 3 hours. Total distance = 240 km. Total time = 5 hours. Average speed = 240/5 = 48 km/h.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Average speed is total distance / total time, not the average of the two speeds. Total distance = 240 km. Total time = 2 + 3 = 5 hours. Average speed = 240/5 = 48 km/h.

questions.question_text: Two friends start walking at the same time. Friend A walks at 4 km/h and Friend B walks at 6 km/h. On a distance-time graph, which statement is correct?

options.text: Both lines have the same slope
Friend B's line is steeper than Friend A's line
Friend A's line is steeper than Friend B's line

questions.explanation_correct: The slope of a distance-time graph represents speed. Since Friend B has a higher speed (6 km/h > 4 km/h), Friend B's line will be steeper. Both lines will be straight since both are in uniform motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A steeper line means greater speed. Since Friend B (6 km/h) is faster than Friend A (4 km/h), Friend B's line is steeper. Both are in uniform motion so both lines are straight, not curved.

questions.question_text: A student says: 'All periodic motions are oscillatory, but all oscillatory motions are not periodic.' Is this statement correct?

options.text: No, it should be reversed: all oscillatory motions are periodic but all periodic motions are not oscillatory
No, all periodic motions are also oscillatory
No, periodic and oscillatory motions are completely different

questions.explanation_correct: All oscillatory motions are periodic because they repeat at regular intervals. However, not all periodic motions are oscillatory. For example, the Earth's revolution around the Sun is periodic but not oscillatory. So the correct statement is the reverse of what the student said.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct relationship is: all oscillatory motions are periodic (they repeat regularly), but not all periodic motions are oscillatory (e.g., circular motion of Earth is periodic but not oscillatory). The student's statement had it backwards.

questions.question_text: A cheetah runs 300 m in 10 seconds. Its speed is ___ m/s, which equals ___ km/h.
questions.explanation_correct: Speed = 300 m / 10 s = 30 m/s. To convert to km/h: 30 x 3.6 = 108 km/h.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Speed = Distance / Time = 300/10 = 30 m/s. To convert m/s to km/h, multiply by 3.6: 30 x 3.6 = 108 km/h.

questions.question_text: Priya measures the time for 10 oscillations of a pendulum as 18 seconds. She then shortens the pendulum and finds 10 oscillations take 14 seconds. What can she conclude?

options.text: Shorter pendulums have longer time periods
Shorter pendulums have shorter time periods
Length does not affect time period

questions.explanation_correct: Original time period = 18/10 = 1.8 s. New time period = 14/10 = 1.4 s. Since the shorter pendulum has a smaller time period, Priya can conclude that shorter pendulums have shorter time periods.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The time period decreased from 1.8 s to 1.4 s when the pendulum was shortened. This clearly shows shorter pendulums have shorter time periods.

questions.question_text: An object's distance-time data shows: 0 s - 0 m, 1 s - 2 m, 2 s - 8 m, 3 s - 18 m, 4 s - 32 m. The distance-time graph for this object will be:

options.text: A straight line passing through the origin
A curve that gets steeper with time
A curve that gets flatter with time

questions.explanation_correct: The distances covered in successive 1-second intervals are: 2 m, 6 m, 10 m, 14 m. Since the distances are increasing, the object is speeding up (non-uniform motion). The distance-time graph will be a curve that gets steeper with time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The object covers increasing distances in equal time intervals (2, 6, 10, 14 m), meaning it is accelerating. This results in a curve that becomes steeper as time progresses, not a straight line.

questions.question_text: A car moving along a winding mountain road is an example of rectilinear motion.
questions.explanation_correct: Rectilinear motion means motion in a straight line. A car moving along a winding road keeps changing its direction, so it is not moving in a straight line. Therefore, it is not rectilinear motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. A winding road involves curves and changes in direction. Rectilinear motion requires movement strictly in a straight line, which is not the case here.

questions.question_text: A bird flies 600 m north in 30 s, rests for 10 s, and then flies 400 m south in 20 s. What is the average speed of the bird for the entire journey?
questions.explanation_correct: Total distance = 600 + 400 = 1000 m. Total time = 30 + 10 + 20 = 60 s. Average speed = Total distance / Total time = 1000/60 = 16.7 m/s (approximately).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Average speed uses total distance (not displacement) and total time (including rest). Total distance = 1000 m, total time = 60 s. Average speed = 1000/60 = 16.7 m/s.
